text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
CAPITAL

- A group led by Trita Fanita, a member of parliament from the Democratic Party, has won a tender for the largest grain terminal in the free trade area of the Black Sea port of Constanta, the newspaper says.
- Romania has increased excise duties on medium-priced foreign cigarettes.
- Production costs for wheat are bigger than market prices, says a newspaper report.
BURSA
- Renel electricity authority has hired British-based consultants Coopers & Lybrand to help to restructure the energy sector.
ADEVARUL

- Romania has been left out of initial membership talks postponed by the European Union after being excluded by NATO, says a report on the European Commission's decision to start membership talks only with five East European countries.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Next week, Romania's Romtelecom state-run telephone operator will announce the winner of a tender bid to size up the company ahead of privatisation.
- The newspaper quotes a report drafted by Britain's The Banker manazine, listing only one Romanian bank, Banca Comerciala Romania (BCR) among the world's top 1,000 banks.
General:
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Former King Michael will go to Timisoara, in western Romania, in August, and spend his summer holidays in his homeland.
- Tinker gypsy clans from two villages near Suceava fought pitched battles over a 13-year old girl, the newspaper says.
ADEVARUL
- Three Romanian convicts, serving eight-year jail terms for robbery, escaped from a Greek prison on the island of Crete, the newspaper says.
- The Hungarian consular office in Cluj will be open for three working days a week, starting July 28, says a newspaper report.
LIBERTATEA

- Half of Romania's school-age Gypsy children don't go to school, according to a survey by a local pollster, which also shows that the number of school drop-outs is three times lower now than in 1989.
-- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
